headline: Manchester United star is making difficult Ruben Amorim transfer decision much easier
body: Ruben Amorim would have been under no illusions as to the challenges facing him when he took on a job the size of Manchester United just over a year ago. But he was perhaps not ready for the constant headaches he would have to deal with. The nature of United means there are very few quiet days.

At the moment, he is currently juggling several issues. An injury crisis is plaguing his team with absentees across the defence and midfield stretching the squad to the maximum. Speculation surrounding the future of Kobbie Mainoo continues to rattle on as does talk of Bruno Fernandes leaving.

This is on top of the everyday challenges of pushing this club back to the heights they once reached. But one topic which has gone under the radar in the past couple of weeks is the contract situations of Casemiro and Harry Maguire.

Both men will be free agents at the end of this season, as things stand. The Brazilian has a clause in his contract which United can utilise to extend his stay in Manchester but Maguire will need to agree to a new deal if he is to stay beyond 2026.

Maguire and Casemiro can both negotiate with overseas clubs freely from the start of January as they enter the final six months of their current deals. In his pre-Newcastle press conference on Christmas Eve, Amorim was asked by MEN Sport if any further talks had taken place with the duo over their Old Trafford deals.

"No, there is no decision, we have a lot to do," Amorim responded. "We need to understand what is going to happen in the next season because we need to understand there are European games, and what we are doing.
"So we have so much to do at this moment. We are not thinking about that. We will think just think about the next game."
He added: "I'm really happy with them, but I don't know what is going to happen, so we will see what will happen until the end of the season, what position we will be, and then we will see."
Whether more is going on behind the scenes than we know remains to be seen, but at least in the case of Maguire, the decision could be being made easier by Ayden Heaven.

The Arsenal academy graduate traded the Emirates Stadium for Old Trafford last January. A matter of weeks prior to that switch he made his first-team debut for the Gunners against Preston North End in the Carabao Cup but it was clear this would be the exception, rather than the rule.

Gabriel and William Saliba are Mikel Arteta's first choices when fit, regardless of who is coming through the academy. Clearly, Heaven felt chances would be easier to come by in Manchester and so it has proved.

In the first half of the year, he was called upon four times in the Premier League. An injury picked up against Leicester City scuppered his momentum and it was obvious this season would be a big one for him.
When he was initially brought in to cover injuries, he underwhelmed which was to be expected given he is still only 19 and he had not played much football since the injury at the King Power Stadium.

But in recent weeks, with Maguire and Matthijs de Ligt out, Heaven has impressed. Against Aston Villa he shone in the centre of the back three and again on Boxing Day, he showed maturity above his years.

The Englishman is starting to look fully at home in the defensive line and his form is beginning to alleviate the pressure surrounding Maguire. Amorim will be the first to say Maguire is more than just a competent defender, he is part of the leadership group and this cannot be understated.
However, Heaven is showing on the pitch he is capable of performing to the required level, even though he is still a teenager. He is a realistic successor to Maguire.

headline: Manchester United have no excuse not to do something they've rarely done under Ruben Amorim
body: Pictures of the Derby County side from 2007/08 usually make their way onto social media platforms at least once a year. As soon as every team in the Premier League has broken through the 11-point barrier, Derby fans are forced to be reminded of the ignominy their side suffered 18 years ago.

Except this season has been a little different, thanks to Wolverhampton Wanderers. Pictures of a dejected Robbie Savage and a furious Danny Mills have been thrown out a little more readily in recent months, with fans debating whether Rob Edwards' Wolves side genuinely could somehow go one 'better' and record a lower points total than Derby managed back in 2007/08.

One game off the halfway point in the Premier League season and Wolves are yet to pick up a win, with their only points coming in draws with Tottenham and Brighton. Manchester United welcome the basement boys to Old Trafford on Tuesday for a game they simply must win.

United are never too far away from the headlines and pundits and rival fans alike need no encouragement to enjoy a laugh at United's expense, yet failure to beat Wolves on Tuesday would merit such treatment. No matter how much optimism fills the Old Trafford air it always feels like United are only ever a couple of games away from a crisis - they're potentially 90 minutes away from one given how dire Wolves have been this season.

When the two sides met at Molineux three weeks ago the home side threatened to make a contest of the game at one point, drawing themselves level on the stroke of half-time. But United stepped it up a gear in the second half and ensured they condemned Wolves to an eighth straight Premier League defeat - that run has since stretched to 11.

A win for United on Tuesday would see them make it back-to-back Premier League wins following the uplifting victory over Newcastle on Boxing Day. A string of three consecutive wins in October 2025 was the only other time United have managed to follow a victory with another three points in the Premier League during the Ruben Amorim era, 14 months on from his appointment.

They could not have asked for a better opportunity to record successive league wins, but making light work of supposedly favourable home contests hasn't been a forte of Amorim's side this season. Prior to the win over Newcastle, United's most recent Old Trafford outings had seen them throw away a late lead to draw 4-4 with Bournemouth - a team that have picked up just four points in the last two months - while they drew with a struggling West Ham side after losing 1-0 to 10-man Everton.
Tuesday should be a home banker but, unfortunately, there's no such thing with this United team. Anything other than a win will be unacceptable.

headline: Man United receive new referee verdict after controversial Lisandro Martinez incident vs Newcastle
body: Former Premier League referee Dermot Gallagher has shared his thoughts on the Lisandro Martinez handball incident from Manchester United's win over Newcastle. The central defender inadvertently blocked a Fabian Schar effort with his arm in the penalty area, though no spot-kick was awarded despite some huge appeals.

United had spent much of the second half defending deeply after Patrick Dorgu's stunning volley put them in front. Ruben Amorim's side ultimately held on for a crucial three points, though things could have been very different had the Magpies been awarded a penalty.
Jay Bothroyd did not agree though and stated: "I don't think that's conclusive. The terminology confused me, they didn't even say it touched his chest."
"I don't even know what 'mutual contact' means. Martinez is grappling. It looks like he's tried to push the defender away, his hands are there and that's an unnatural position.
"But if they said it hits his body and then his arms, we don't have this conversation now. The terminology is confusing for me. They're digging themselves a hole."

The incident was checked by Stuart Atwell on VAR, but it was deemed to not be a clear and obvious error. On Co-commentary, Gary Neville described the controversial moment in detail and came to the same conclusion.
"There is a massive shout, he said. "Schar hits it, his arm is up above his head, and it's stretched. Is it because he's pushing [Malick] Thiaw?
"That might just save him. He's actually wrestling with the other Newcastle centre-back; his arms are already there.
"If Thiaw is nowhere near him, that's definitely a penalty. I think the fact that he has just had a wrestle with the other centre-back might just save him."
Neville added: "He is saying the context is because there's another situation whereby he is fighting with another player and his arms are already up there and he's just not got back down."
Keith Hackett, who is the former general manager of Professional Game Match Officials Limited (PGMOL), was in agreement with Gallagher and Neville.

He told Football Insider: "The referee has to judge if the action by the player is deliberate when deciding that an offence has taken place, not every time the ball comes into contact, is it an offence.
"There is sufficient doubt in this action not to award a penalty kick."

headline: Man United can sign dream Bruno Fernandes team-mate as 'approaches' made for January transfer
body: Ruben Amorim's midfield in Manchester United's Premier League win over Newcastle United last week consisted of two players who aren't guaranteed to still be at the club next season.
With Bruno Fernandes nursing a hamstring injury and Kobbie Mainoo out with a minor issue, Manuel Ugarte and Casemiro lined up in the middle of the park amid speculation over their futures.

Before Fernandes pulled up at Villa Park, United were approaching the January transfer window knowing that a new midfielder would need to be signed at the right price. Amorim has since come out and said the club have to get the transfer decisions spot on and avoid any mistakes.

"I think we can improve [our depth]," he said. "Of course, we have space to have more players, but I think the important thing in our club, is that we have a plan. We need to bring in players that we know.

"It's hard to know for sure that everything is going to work, but we need to be certain of the choice, the players that we bring. If e are not sure, if everyone is not aligned, it's better not to bring anyone and to work with the players that we have.

If United's plan before Fernandes' injury was to test Brighton's resolve on Carlos Baleba or turn their attention to cheaper alternatives, it will now be altered. The absence of their talisman, even if it's just for a month, means a new midfielder will have to be acquired regardless.

Amorim has also stated that any exits will have to be replaced, meaning Mainoo's possible loan move could open the door for another incoming player. And when news from Saudi Arabia emerges that Ruben Neves wasn't interested in extending his contract at Al-Hilal, everything points towards the ex-Wolves man being a dream January signing.

After being heavily linked with a move to Old Trafford during his Wolves days, Neves left England for Saudi Arabia in 2023. Now, it's understood that Al-Hilal are hoping to receive a transfer fee in January instead of losing him in the summer for nothing.

A fee of £15million has been touted, and that would be splendid business for United. At 28, the midfielder is a regular in the Portugal national team, capable of playing as a holding midfielder and playmaker and would be the dream partner to Fernandes.

Data collected by transfermarkt claims that the pair have played together 62 times for Portugal. Dating back to their time together with the Under-21s, the pair are now regulars for the senior team and a move would significantly improve United's midfield.

According to the reporter Fabrizio Romano, Neves still has no intentions of signing a new deal with Al-Hilal and 'several' European top clubs have made approaches over a January move. It hasn't been confirmed whether United are among those clubs, but their previous interest and current situation make them a strong candidate to be one of them.

headline: Kai Rooney response speaks volumes as Man United sent clear message
body: Kai Rooney says he hopes to be playing on the biggest stage with the best players and winning trophies five years from now.
Rooney, 16, was asked on Instagram by The Talent Hunter where he hopes to be in five years. He replied: "Playing on the biggest stage amongst the best players, winning trophies.

The forward began playing for Manchester United's under-18s this season at the age of 15, a few months before his birthday in November. Rooney made his debut as a substitute during their 1-0 win against his father Wayne's boyhood club, Everton, at Finch Farm back in August.

He then came off the bench in their next match and scored the fifth goal in a 5-0 win over Middlesbrough at Carrington. Rooney, however, sustained an injury during the opening weeks of this season and has only recently returned to the pitch for Darren Fletcher's team.

The forward was back on the bench for United's Premier League Cup game against Birmingham City and scored their sixth goal in a 6-0 win. After that match, he posted a photo on Instagram with the caption: "We back babyyyyyyy."
Marcus Rashford liked the posted and commented with a football emoji. The likes of Chido Obi, Jack Fletcher, JJ Gabriel and Shea Lacey were also among his teammates who showed their support.

Fletcher and Lacey both made the first-team bench at Old Trafford for their Boxing Day match against Newcastle United. The former replaced Mason Mount at half-time after debuting alongside Lacey during the defeat to Aston Villa before Christmas.
Ruben Amorim spoke at length about the opportunities for academy players following United's win over Newcastle. He said: "We have a squad and I try to choose the best players to play.
"I understand the history of the club. I want to be part of that.
"Sometimes, you just need to choose the best players to win. Today was the opposite of many games; we put players of the academy in because we had to do it, and they deserved it."
Speaking specifically about Fletcher, the United head coach said: "It's very important for any kid. He is going to hear from his father already.
"I know Darren is going to talk about a lot of things, but he needs to back up, calm down, and just praise the kid because he's really humble. He works really hard and deserves this."

Kai hopes to hear similar things said about himself and Wayne in the years to come. His father spoke to the BBC about Kai while in Northern Ireland to watch him at SuperCupNI, an international youth football tournament formerly known as the Milk Cup.

Rooney Snr said: "He has great coaches at Manchester United, so I take a stand-off approach. I speak to him, but for me it's all about his mentality and his mindset, to make sure he keeps enjoying it - that's the main thing for me."

headline: Man United can sanction January transfer with 'smart' move as Manuel Ugarte claims emerge
body: The January transfer window opens this week and Manchester United will be assessing all options to improve Ruben Amorim's team. Unlike this time last year, United are sitting high in the Premier League and aren't desperate for reinforcements on a big scale.
Beating Newcastle United on Boxing Day and the subsequent results around them mean Ruben Amorim's men are sixth, level on points with Chelsea in fifth and just three behind Liverpool in the top four.

On Tuesday, they welcome Wolves to Old Trafford, looking to keep their hunt for Champions League football alive. But before then, transfer talk is gathering pace quickly. Bruno Fernandes' injury means United are expected to make a move for a new midfielder next month.
Joshua Zirkzee is a wanted man, with a return to Italy heavily tipped. According to reports, AS Roma are keen to bring him back to Serie A, but face difficulty in tempting United with a move.

La Gazzetta dello Sport have claimed that the striker has held positive discussions with Roma. However, United are only expected to let him leave should they bring in a replacement. Step forward, Lassine Sinayoko.

The Auxerre striker has caught the eye of football scouts with two goals in Mali's opening two AFCON games, and according to AfricaFoot, United have held discussions with his entourage over a potential move. His contract in France expires in the summer, meaning he could be available on a pre-contract or at a low price.

MEN Sport says: "Sinayoko isn't a name that many would be familiar with. A striker in France, and not one of the big clubs, isn't going to be one fans would see coming, but if Zirkzee is to leave, signing a striker who will be willing to play behind Benjamin Sesko would be smart business.

"He has bagged six times in France this season, and his heroics for his country this month have put eyes on him. Zirkzee hasn't impressed massively under Amorim and with the World Cup around the corner, a move seems certain for him."

Galatasaray are one of the teams paying close interest to Manuel Ugarte's situation at United. According to reports in Turkey, the Turkish giants are putting plans in place ahead of January with a move eyed.

Despite interest from Lyon and Napoli, it is claimed that Galatasaray are set to send a package to United, which would see the midfielder join the club on loan for the remainder of the season before he moves permanently for €25million (£21.7m) in the summer.
The report also adds that Ugarte's Uruguay teammates, Fernando Muslera and Lucas Torreira, could be key in making a move happen.

MEN Sport says: "United's priority in January has to be a midfielder, so allowing Ugarte to leave would mean they would have to replace him. And while the move from Galatasaray is only a loan, it would guarantee them a fee in the summer.

"There are different ways to look at this from United's point of view, and the best-case scenario for them is to bank the cash and prioritise their incomings. For example, they could use the money to sign Ruben Neves at the reported £15million fee he's available for.
"Better yet, the sale of Ugarte in the summer and removal of Casemiro's wages, should he depart on a free, could open up room in the kitty to spend big at the end of the season."

headline: Rasmus Hojlund Napoli verdict speaks volumes as Man United striker sends five-word message
body: Rasmus Hojlund was on the scoresheet once again for Napoli this weekend as the Manchester United loanee continued to showcase his ability in front of goal this season.

The striker scored both goals as the Italian champions defeated Cremonese on Sunday, in his latest statement for the Naples-based side. He has now scored seven goals in 19 appearances this season, just three less than the ten he managed for United last term.

Hojlund moved to italy on a season-long loan on deadline day after United opted to spend big on Benjamin Sesko. The deal includes an obligation for Napoli sign the Denmark international on a permanent deal if they qualify for the Champions League.
Following the win in Cremona, Hojlund took to Instagram to post a message to his fans. Posing with the Serie A Man of the Match trophy, he wrote: "Christmas came late this year."

Bryan Mbeumo, Patrick Dorgu, Andre Onana and Ethan Wheatley were among the thousands who liked the striker's post within the first hour. Napoli boss Antonio Conte went on to praise his striker following the win, in comments that spoke volumes about the player's standing in his side: "Hojlund is a player who, first of all, is very young, but above all, has a lot of room for improvement.
"He's becoming a dominant player in that position. He's very connected to the team. In my style of football, everyone knows that strikers have a very important and unique role.

"The road to success? Annibale said that there isn't a road, it has to be built. We are doing it despite the great difficulties." He added: "We're celebrating a wonderful year where we achieved something extraordinary and unexpected.

"We crowned the Scudetto with the Super Cup, where we beat Milan and Bologna. It was a wonderful year, full of emotions. Napoli, when you win, makes you celebrate in a different way. We're up there in the league and we're trying to stay close to the top spots. This season, we're facing several challenges, and we're always facing them with courage."

Hojlund form comes amid doubts about United's current attacking options. Sesko has managed just two goals since his move from RB Leipzig, and Joshua Zirkzee has been tipped to secure a return to Italy in January.

However, Amorim has admitted that a move for any of his players next month will only be completed if they can bring in a replacement. "It's going to be hard for someone to leave the club if we don't get a substitution," he said.

"We are a club with a big responsibility. We are dealing with all these issues and in [the media's] heads, in my head, in everybody's head, we need to win every game. It doesn't matter. There are no excuses."

headline: RAILSTON: United defender Patrick Dorgu responds to Ruben Amorim criticism - 'Never nice'
body: Manchester United defender Patrick Dorgu believes he has responded to Ruben Amorim's criticism with his recent performances. At the end of November, Amorim said he could feel "anxiety" from Dorgu when he picked up the ball, and suggested the Denmark international needed to perform better.
"He needs to be calmer playing the game," said Amorim to a question about what Dorgu needs to improve. "You can feel the anxiety every time Patrick touches the ball. I can feel the anxiety."
Following that press conference, Dorgu lost his starting place. He was named on the bench for the next five matches, but he was recalled to the starting team against Aston Villa last weekend.

The 21-year-old assisted Matheus Cunha for United's goal in the Midlands and delivered another improved performance against Newcastle, scoring in the first half with a brilliant volley to claim three points for United.

Dorgu spoke to reporters following the full-time whistle and was asked how he dealt with the criticism. "Of course it's never nice to get criticism, but you will always get it as a player," he said. "And you need to react well to it, and I think I've reacted well in the last couple of games."
He added: "The manager spoke about my confidence a few weeks ago, so I just looked inside and tried to understand what he meant. And I just tried to build myself up."

Dorgu sought advice from the leadership group in the dressing room, which includes Bruno Fernandes, Diogo Dalot, Noussair Mazraoui, Lisandro Martinez, Harry Maguire and Tom Heaton. "My teammates help me as well," he added. I spoke to Bruno [Fernandes] and some of the leader group in my team. They just try to help me on a daily basis to grow in confidence in training and stuff. "

Dorgu continued: "We have players at AFCON and injured players, so this is my chance to show I belong in this team, and I feel like I'm doing it in the last couple of games, so I just need to keep going and try to keep the manager happy."

Dorgu played on the right, in a more prominent position, against Newcastle. "I've done that in my old team as well, so it's nothing new to me. I'm just happy to score the goal," he said. "I've been training to shoot more in the games and I think I hit it really well. I'm really happy that it went in. I knew already a few days ago [about playing on the right], so I just tried to remember how to play there.
"It's the same, just you come inside to your stronger foot, so sometimes it's even easier to attack and connect with the teammates, so I find it really easy."

headline: Manchester United handed transfer timeline as player 'says yes' to move
body: The January transfer window is just around the corner, and Manchester United are said to have a number of names that they hope to pursuit. However, there could also be outgoing stars who have failed to make a mark at Old Trafford.

Following a 1-0 win over Newcastle United on Friday evening thanks to Patrick Dorgu's first-half strike, the Reds currently sit fifth in the Premier League standings A tally of eight wins, five draws and as many losses is what Ruben Amorim's men have to show for their efforts this season, as they look to push for European qualification.

It's a polar opposite state of affairs from the club's 15th-place finish for 2024/25, but further investment may be required next month to ensure a strong end to the current campaign. With the market reopening in a matter of days now, the rumour mill has been churning with regards to both arrivals and departures.

As per Gazzetta, Joshua Zirkzee has had a number of "discussions and contacts" with Roma management as of recent, particularly speaking with sporting director, Ricky Massara, and Giallorossi head coach, Gian Piero Gasperini. The publication claim that the Dutch forward has gone as far as "promising" himself to Roma by saying 'yes' to a move when the window opens, as it looks increasingly likely that he will make a grand return to Serie A in mid-January, when Bryan Mbeumo, Amad and Noussair Mazraoui return from AFCON.

However, there is a crutch with regards to United agreeing a deal without finding a suitable replacement. While Mbeumo, Benjamin Sesko and Matheus Cunha have all seen the nod ahead of the 24-year-old, Zirkzee has been a valuable option with regards to depth, featuring in 10 Premier League matches this season.

A loan deal with an obligation to buy looks the most likely scenario for Zirkzee come January, should Roma be happy to agree to a fee of around £35million to take the forward on permanently come season's end. With United seemingly looking to strengthen their engine room next month, it will be interesting to see which names crop up as a potential replacement for Zirkzee.

The MEN says: On paper, a deal with Roma would be a fantastic move for all parties involved. Zirkzee set United back a reported £36.5m last summer when he joined from Bologna, but has failed to make much of a mark in the English top flight.

At the time of writing, he has scored just eight goals from 61 appearances - a stark contrast to the 14 from 58 he managed with Bologna - and should Roma agree to a £35m obligation to buy, it will see the Reds recoup most of the money they paid for him last summer to spend elsewhere.

United are among a wealth of clubs who are currently said to be keeping tabs on AZ prospect, Kees Smit. The 19-year-old midfielder has impressed in the Eredivisie, having broken through the youth academy last year.

This season, the Dutch U21 has racked up two goals and two assists from 15 appearances, instrumental in his club's success as they sit sixth in the league standings. And as a result, a number of teams across the world have had their heads turned.

It's no secret that the Reds are looking to strengthen their engine room in January, given Bruno Fernandes has dropped into a deeper role alongside an ageing Casemiro who sees his future with the club beyond 2025/26 cast into speculation.

However, they will face stiff competition in securing his signature from the likes of Chelsea, Bayern Munich, Barcelona, Newcastle United and Real Madrid, to name a few. Furthermore, AZ are understood to hold a valuation of around £52m on the talent at present, which could prove risky considering he is fairly unproven.

The MEN says: It's a major risk to fork out such a substantial sum on a rising prospect, especially given United's track record with regards to splurging on wonderkids as of recent. Zirkzee and Rasmus Hojlund are examples, with neither player truly living up to expectations at Old Trafford despite their reputation.

Instead, the Reds may be better suited tailing a slightly older player with Premier League experience such as Elliot Anderson, considering the centre of the park is make or break in terms of team success.

headline: RAILSTON: What Ruben Amorim did offers fresh Manchester United hope as Newcastle staff left confused
body: Manchester United won 1-0 against Newcastle in the Premier League on Boxing Day. United opened the scoring in the 24th minute through a brilliant Patrick Dorgu goal, which was the difference at the break. Newcastle started the second half as the better team and came close to equalising, hitting the crossbar, but United defended bravely to see out a victory, which means they move to fifth in the table. Here are the moments you might have missed....
Amorim sprang a surprise with his system in the 4-4 draw against Bournemouth earlier this month and he tweaked his tactics again on Boxing Day, starting the match with a 4-2-3-1 shape.
The biggest surprise was Dorgu's position, as he started practically on the right wing. The Newcastle analysts in the press box sounded and looked confused as they deliberated among themselves.

Amorim has been wedded to the 3-4-3 formation for most of his tenure, but he is finally tweaking his approach depending on the opponent, which can only be a positive. The United boss has shown a willingness to change, and the reaction from Newcastle's analysts proves why it's worth being adaptable.
Newcastle struggled to get to grips with the shape in the opening exchanges. They eventually adapted and warmed to the contest, but it's encouraging to see Amorim tweaking his tactics game by game.

Amorim altered his system again when he made a double change in the second half. Then Newcastle's analysts were overheard questioning whether Dalot was the right-sided winger. Amorim famously said not even the Pope could persuade him to change his tactics, but that stance has softened.
Dorgu had scored just 12 goals in his career before facing Newcastle, so it's likely his wonderful volley from the edge of the box to fire United into the lead was his finest strike so far.
The Denmark international savoured every second of the celebrations, but he was hungry for more after the restart, demanding the ball from his teammates at every possible opportunity.

Dorgu frantically waved his arms to receive the ball in the 27th minute before looping a shot over the bar. Just moments later, he wildy gestured at Luke Shaw to pass it to him from the opposite wing.
It's funny what confidence can do to a player. Dorgu looked like a new signing and delivered the kind of performance that he must produce consistently to nail down a regular starting role.
Matheus Cunha had an opportunity to extend United's advantage with 10 minutes remaining, but his shot was sent wide of the post at the Stretford End, to the relief of Aaron Ramsdale.
Cunha was slumped on the turf and looked like he had nothing else in the tank. The forward had worked tirelessly throughout the game, and he took his time to get back to his feet.

There were suggestions that Cunha's work rate could be an issue before his arrival from Wolves in the summer transfer window. Some pundits suggested he would not provide adequate defensive cover. Cunha has made that look stupid in just a few months in Manchester - he runs his socks off each game.
Dorgu didn't just contribute in the final third against Newcastle, he worked back and provided defensive cover, which saw him make one of the tackles of the game on Lewis Hall.

It was a brilliant challenge, which provoked a roar from the Stretford End. Dorgu also received appreciation from his teammates. Diogo Dalot slapped his back, and Casemiro pushed him as if to say 'more of that'.

The crowd lapped up Casemiro's interaction. The Brazilian received praise from Amorim during the pre-Newcastle press conference and it will be difficult to find a replacement with a similar mentality next summer, but logic dictates it's the right decision to allow Casemiro to leave after the expiry of his contract.

United included brothers on the bench for the first time in 12 years against Newcastle, with Amorim naming Jack Fletcher and Tyler Fletcher in the squad. Jack was handed his debut against Aston Villa, and he was joined by his twin brother, Tyler, who made his first Premier League matchday squad.

Darren Fletcher, their father, looked proud as punch in the directors' box. It was a special moment to have both brothers in the squad, and the occasion became even sweeter when Jack came onto the pitch.
Mason Mount was brought off at the interval - seemingly due to an injury - and Fletcher was introduced. His father was on his feet and applauding following the final whistle.

headline: Ruben Amorim now one game away from unexpected Man United boost amid anxious AFCON wait
body: Patrick Dorgu has gone full circle at Manchester United this month and Ruben Amorim will now have everything crossed that his first signing for the club can avoid an unwanted suspension. Dorgu, who was a match-winner for United against Newcastle on Boxing Day, is walking a disciplinary tightrope amid his marked improvement.
Dorgu, 21, has four yellow cards to his name this season. Picking up five before the 19-game mark of a term in turn results in a one-match suspension for any Premier League player.

That means Dorgu - and his manager - have 90 anxious minutes to get through against Wolves next up with three teammates unavailable due to AFCON and Bruno Fernandes among those still injured. After being cast aside and publicly criticised by Amorim just a few weeks ago, Dorgu has returned to the line-up with an assist (vs Aston Villa) and goal (vs Newcastle) to help United feel a lot more comfortable without so many options.
"He needs to be calmer playing the game," said Amorim when he was asked about what Dorgu needs to improve. "You can feel the anxiety every time Patrick touches the ball. I can feel the anxiety."

Following that press conference, Dorgu lost his starting place. He was then named on the subs bench for the next five matches, but was recalled against Villa - making his mark in that game and the Newcastle win.

Dorgu spoke with reporters following the full-time whistle vs Newcastle and he was asked how he dealt with the criticism. "Of course it's never nice to get criticism, but you will always get it as a player," he said. "And you need to react well to it, and I think I've reacted well in the last couple of games."
He added: "The manager spoke about my confidence a few weeks ago. I just looked inside and tried to understand what he meant. And I just tried to build myself up."

A sure-fire starter against Wolves (December 30), Dorgu has found a new place in the reshuffled line-up. However, one slip up against the rock-bottom side will see the Denmark man banned for the next Premier League after that, which just happens to be against Leeds.
Amorim will want - and need - to have the former Lecce player available for that trip to Elland Road. He might not have thought that would be the case a few weeks ago.

Recalled out of necessity due to AFCON selection for three others, Dorgu has - at first viewing - taken his chance. The last thing he will now want to do will relinquish his hold on the shirt and present a similar opportunity to other player in Amorim's squad.
Dorgu was signed by Amorim during last season's January transfer window. He cost £30million.
So far in United colours, the wing-back-turned-forward has totted-up 38 matches. The goal against Newcastle was his first for the club, while he also has three assists to show for his efforts.
Dorgu has been capped 12 times by Denmark at senior level. He's under contract at Old Trafford until 2030.

headline: Manchester United vs Newcastle LIVE goal and score updates
body: Patrick Dorgu's superb volley midway through the first half proved to be the difference as Ruben Amorim's side secured a precious three points. The Reds were the better side in the first half but came under huge pressure in the second with a resolute rearguard action keeping the visitors out.

Lewis Hall hit the bar for Newcastle, as did Benjamin Sesko for United while Diogo Dalot missed a glorious chance on the counter for the home side. Newcastle were far superior in the second period but lacked quality in the final third and United earned just a second clean sheet of the campaign and a first home win in two months.
Catch up on the action and follow the reaction with us on the blog

A few months ago, Ruben Amorim said even the Pope couldn't convince him to change his system at Manchester United, but on the second day of Christmas, he gave in to popular demand. If a back three is United's past, then could this back four be their future?

Amorim had been teasing the idea of a change of shape in recent weeks and had worked on it in training, so the ghosts of Christmas hadn't visited him in his sleep and brought about an epiphany, yet however it came about, Old Trafford delighted in the reversion to a flat back four and the end of wing-backs.

There is enough material from the past 13 months to give Amorim nightmares, but this change in formation delivered a change in fortunes as well. After six weeks of blowing chance after chance to go fifth in the Premier League, they finally took it. It might last for less than 24 hours, but it shows that this side is in the hunt for a Champions League spot, even if they spent almost the entire second half on the back foot.
Read Tyrone Marshall's on the whistle analysis here
United were pinned back for much of the second half and had to produce a defensive rearguard to hold on to the lead given them before the break.
That goal came from an unlikely source. A half-cleared long throw fell invitingly for Patrick Dorgu, who hit a first-time left-foot volley into the bottom corner from 16 yards.
That's the final whistle at Old Trafford.
United are defending bravely in these final minutes.

United are absorbing the Newcastle pressure and counter-attacking when they win the ball.
Dalot gets in behind and comes close to making it 2-0 but he cannot keep it down.
Newcastle wanted a penalty and VAR checked the incident - but it was not given.
Hall hits the crossbar from the edge of the box.

United are sitting back in their shape and defending well against Newcastle's probing.
Newcastle have won a few corners in quick succession and have started this half as the better side.

Sesko can be pleased with his work so far. That was an excellent leap to win a header against Thiaw and start another United attack. He has looked more comfortable leading the line in this shape, as has players around him and is holding the ball up well.
Dorgu is full of confidence and asking for the ball at every single opportunity.

Amorim was just starting to get agitated on the touchline before that goal. United had been on the back foot for a good 10 minutes and were looking ragged. That came out of nowhere, but what a hit it was. Nobody will be anxious when Dorgu is on the ball again anytime soon.
Dorgu has just scored a screamer from the edge of the box to fire United into the lead.
That was an incredible technique to volley and find the bottom left corner.

After being caught by surprise due to the system, Newcastle have grown into this game.
Newcastle came close to scoring through a Guimaraes header at a corner.

The Newcastle analysts in the press box have been trying to work out new pressing patterns for United’s unexpected shape. There is a fair bit of shoulder shrugging going on. Nobody expected Dorgu to start on the right wing. Howe and Tindall have been deep in discussions as well, with messages passed on to players who were clearly expecting a more familiar United set-up.
Newcastle's analysts in the press box sound and look confused by how United have lined up tonight.

It was a hybrid back four/back three against Bournemouth but this looks like a back four. Dalot and Shaw the full-backs and Heaven and Martinez in the middle. Dorgu has started very high on the right and is up with Cunha and Sesko at times.
Casemiro had a completely free header in the box but he's unable to get it on target.
It looks like a back four tonight. Dorgu has started high on the right side, similar to where Amad played in the draw against Bournemouth. Amorim is tweaking his tactics due to missing key players.

headline: Mount, Fernandes, Mainoo - Man United injury latest and return dates vs Wolves
body: Manchester United got back to winning ways as they secured a 1-0 victory over Newcastle. Patrick Dorgu's first-half strike was enough for United to secure all three points in the Boxing Day clash at Old Trafford.

Ruben Amorim's side were forced to go into the game without club captain Bruno Fernandes available for selection. Fernandes is currently sidelined with a muscle injury that he suffered during the defeat to Aston Villa last week.
United will now prepare to face Wolves in their next Premier League match, which will take place on Tuesday night on home soil.
Bruno Fernandes is expected to be unavailable for a few weeks for United with a muscle injury.
Fernandes missed the win over Newcastle on Boxing Day, which was only the third game the Portugal international has missed due to injury during his time at United.
Potential return date: January
Mason Mount was forced off at half-time in the win against Newcastle. Amorim said the midfielder 'felt something' before being taken off.
"He wanted to go [on] and that is also a good thing," added Amorim. "He wanted to go to the second half but we cannot lose more players, if you are not 100 per cent."
Potential return date: December 30 vs Wolves (H) or January 4 vs Leeds United (A)
Kobbie Mainoo is on the sidelines with a calf injury that has forced him to miss United's last two matches.
A return is not too far away, but it's unclear if the England international will return in time to face Wolves or be forced to wait for the following fixture in the New Year.
Potential return date: December 30 vs Wolves (H) or January 4 vs Leeds United (A)
Matthijs de Ligt has been on the sidelines for several weeks with a back injury but is moving closer to a return to action.
United will be hoping to have De Ligt in the squad to face Wolves on Tuesday, with Amorim expected to provide an update when the head coach speaks to the media ahead of the fixture next week.
Potential return date: December 30 vs Wolves (H)
Harry Maguire is continuing to recover from an injury and could return to United's matchday squad when they face Wolves on Tuesday night next week.
Maguire has been sidelined for several weeks with the injury but is closing in on a return, but it remains to be seen if the defender will be available to face Wolves.
Potential return date: December 30 vs Wolves (H)
Bryan Mbeumo is currently unavailable for United while he continues to star for Cameroon at the Africa Cup of Nations.
The forward will return in January after his country has either been eliminated from the tournament or won the competition.
Potential return date: January
Amad Diallo is also unavailable for United while he stars for the Ivory Coast at the Africa Cup of Nations.
Potential return date: January
Noussair Mazraoui remains unavailable for United while he continues to star for Morocco at AFCON, which is being held in his home country.
Potential return date: January

headline: Ruben Amorim explains Manchester United decision vs Newcastle - 'Bruno is not there'
body: Ruben Amorim has explained that Lisandro Martinez is wearing the captain's armband against Newcastle because he is part of Manchester United's leadership group, which was formed in the summer. Amorim has made two changes from Villa Park last weekend, dropping Leny Yoro to the bench in favour of starting Martinez, who is skipper in the absence of Bruno Fernandes. Casemiro also returns from suspension.

"We need to perform well. We need to be physical. They [Newcastle] need to feel uncomfortable. We need to be smart - we cannot lose the ball in our half when we are too exposed or open. We know what they want and we will try to do the opposite, but we also need to play with our strengths."

When asked about Martinez wearing the armband, Amorim said: "We made a list at the beginning of the season, Lisandro was on that list. He is going to wear the armband but everyone needs to step up because Bruno is not here."
He added about the youthful bench: "They are ready to help the team. We have a short squad to give the kids an opportunity. They are really proud to be here. If we need, they will be on the pitch."

Amorim was without multiple key players at Villa Park last weekend, but Newcastle have a dismal away record this season although they did win 2-0 at Old Trafford last December, in what was a miserable month for Amorim. The Magpies beat United 4-1 at St James' Park when the two sides met again in April.

headline: RAILSTON: Manchester United manager Ruben Amorim makes Kobbie Mainoo transfer admission
body: Ruben Amorim admitted it would be "hard" to sanction a loan exit for Kobbie Mainoo if Manchester United cannot replace him. Mainoo has not started for United in the Premier League this season. The youngster was potentially in line to receive his first start against Aston Villa last weekend, but he picked up a calf injury in training and was ruled out of that match in Birmingham.

The 20-year-old requested to leave on loan in the summer transfer window and could request to leave again in the January window when he returns from the sidelines. However, Bruno Fernandes picked up a muscle injury against Aston Villa and United's midfield options will be lighter during his absence.
Amorim admitted the moving parts could mean a potential request to leave on loan from Mainoo would be rejected. "If we are not getting someone [in], then we are shorter," he said.

"Even with a full squad, we are shorter when something can happen here. We are a club with a big responsibility, we are dealing with all these issues and in your head, my head, and everyone's heads, we need to win every game, it doesn't matter, there are no excuses, so it's going to be hard for someone to leave the club if we don't get a substitution [new signing]."
When asked whether Mainoo could kick on when he returns to fitness in the absence of Fernandes, Amorim said: "Kobbie Mainoo will have the opportunity that he has all the time.

"He played in different positions and we talk about the position of Casemiro - he can do that. He can play, if you play with three, like we did in the last game, the position of Mason Mount in this game, he can play there.
"He is going to be the future of Manchester United. That is my feeling, so he just needs to wait for his chance and everything can change in football, even in two days."

United's target is to seal a return to European football this season, but Amorim would not predict whether his squad could qualify for the Champions League if no new signings are made in the January window.
"I think it's hard to talk about that," he said. "What I can say is we have the potential to do more, and I think I can do more with the team, and I can help the team to be better. That I can say.

"If it's top four, it's different in our club, not everything around our club is so simple. We have the talent to reach it, but there is so much more than that in the team. The only thing I can say is that if we have the full squad, I think I can help them to play better and we can be better in the future."

headline: Senne Lammens 'can become the best in the world' - Manchester United have a new star
body: Senne Lammens wore a polo shirt and a navy sweatshirt when he visited Old Trafford after signing for Manchester United. The young goalkeeper looked as though he could be joining United to work in their HR department.
The same observation was made when Lammens reported for international duty with Belgium last week - the 23-year-old was dressed in a beige collared jacket, a khaki t-shirt and chinos.

"By accident, I saw an article saying he was wearing something boring when he reported for international duty and fans saying they hoped he stays like this," laughed Hayk Milkon, one of Lammens' former coaches.
"This 'boringness' is just the way Senne is, he's really calm and no excesses. He focuses on what he needs to focus on and is open with the people around him. He keeps his feet on the ground."

If Lammens looks like someone who could work in an office, every workplace would love to have him in their five-a-side team. United believe they have signed a young goalkeeper with huge potential, and fans who were present at Old Trafford against Sunderland left the stadium buzzing about his debut.
The quirk is that Lammens appears to be a different person when he wears his goalkeeper kit. He made a supremely confident United debut, aggressively commanded his area and kept a clean sheet.
Milkon coached Lammens during their time together at Club Brugge. Milkon is now the youngest manager in the Belgian top-flight and Lammens plays for the biggest club in England.
"It was Senne with his headphones on. He would go into the gym to do his recovery or some extra top-ups. Or he would just go to relax by playing basketball - he loved to play basketball."

Milkon coached in different roles at Club Brugge. He was the assistant of Club NXT (their reserve team), served as their interim manager, was in charge of the Under-18s and eventually became a first-team coach.
His time at Club Brugge coincided with Lammens progressing from the academy to their first team, so he is uniquely positioned to provide insight into United's new goalkeeper signing.

Lammens joined Club Brugge's academy when he was 12. "He was a guy with huge potential," said Milkon. "As I learned from colleagues who had worked with him when he was much younger, I heard there was a moment that clicked in his head when he became super professional.
"He was one of the guys during Covid - when the players were not able to train - who was doing a lot at home, he was really going far with this to be the best in these types of areas.
"Then he continued like this when he joined the first team to train with them. He always wanted to improve. We also had something in place to look at the parameters on which goalkeepers are judged.
"You see the potential of the goalkeeper based on what they do in games; so their positioning, their decision-making and so on, and Senne was always quite high in these areas.
"The only bad luck that he had was that the first-team goalkeeper was Simon Mignolet. He's an amazing goalkeeper, so it was difficult for Senne to stay over there in the role of No.2.
"That would have also blocked his growth, so it was good for him in the end to make the step to go to Antwerp and he did a tremendous job there. It was amazing to see how fast he adapted."
Milkon continued: "I think for us at Club Brugge, it was very clear to everyone that Senne was a top goalkeeper. He would have been the perfect fit for Club Brugge to be the No.1.
"That was not possible because Mignolet was there. But the parameters that we used to judge his performances indicated he was ticking so many boxes already, and he was consistently doing it.

"There weren't ups and downs with his performances. He was consistently really high and when you compare this to the top goalkeepers, you have a benchmark to say 'Ok, what potential does this guy have?'
"He had some chances with the first team at Club Brugge and made a mistake, or maybe two, but in the end it was very clear to everyone that he was a top goalkeeper.
"It was impossible to try to extend his contract because, again, you have Mignolet, and you cannot block a guy like this. You know he has to go out, he has to play, and he will improve even more."

When asked about Lammens' strengths, he said: "I would say that his decision-making was very good. He is very calm, he sees the solutions on the pitch, he has a quick reaction time and understands the balance between risk and reward, and which decisions are the right ones to make.

"His clean passing is great, his footwork was really good, and he's just an amazing goalkeeper with the shot-stopping. He made some incredible saves back then already. He's quite a complete goalkeeper.
"But making the right decisions at a very young age, being very mature with this, was really impressive. And the fact that he is good with both feet is another big strength.
"For me, Senne is a very calm guy and has all the qualities to be a top professional. That was my impression when I first met him when he was younger and he never changed."

Lammens joined Royal Antwerp on a free transfer in the summer of 2023. He was handed his debut a few months later and served as an understudy that season, but earned first-choice status for 2024/2025.
His performances drew attention from the Belgian media. Lammens saved four penalties across a successful first full campaign and received a call-up to Belgium's senior squad in March.

Milkon said: "I was not surprised when I saw Manchester United had come calling. And to record his first clean sheet, I was really happy for him. Senne is a potential No.1 for the Red Devils - the Belgium national team.

"He got his chance, he took it, and we're all really proud of him, but we knew it would happen. I believe he has all the capabilities to become the best in the world, so I wish him all the best. I'm sure he will have a very good career in England, and Manchester United should return to the big club they used to be.
"He will have a positive impact on that, for sure, and hopefully he will be Belgium's first-choice goalkeeper soon. I believe he has the potential, the skillset and the personality to do that.
"For me, it was just having a tiny little part in having an influence on him at Brugge, but it was the most positive memories of our relationship that we had during this spell.

"I'm very proud that he is reaching these high levels and not surprised. I believe he will be successful because he is a guy who will not change his focus or start to do something different. He is calm, that's his personality and character, and he wants to succeed. He is hungry and will keep working to be his best.

"He is so calm, and you have to be patient in football. You cannot worry too much and want things too early, but finding the balance between not being impatient and, at the same time, pushing and demanding what you deserve in a good way, means everything will sort itself out."
United staff who have worked with Lammens at Carrington have echoed Milkon's sentiments. He has been described as "really mature for his age" and is said to have taken the move in his stride.

Lammens is understood to have impressed coaches during training sessions and a United source said that lots of people have been speaking positively about him. He has already relocated from the luxury hotel where he was initially staying and into a house.
It's no surprise that Lammens likes to play basketball at 6ft 3in, but he is a keen golfer, which is common ground with the likes of Tom Heaton, Luke Shaw, Mason Mount and Harry Maguire.

Matthijs de Ligt, Amad, Maguire and Shaw jogged straight to Lammens to congratulate him after full-time against Sunderland. "Are you Schmeichel in disguise?" was chanted at Lammens from the Stretford End.
It remains to be seen whether Lammens will start against Liverpool on Sunday, but it would be a surprise to see him on the bench after delivering a strong debut before the international break.
There would be nothing boring about keeping another clean sheet - this time at Anfield.

headline: Man Utd have a ‘new destination’ for Marcus Rashford as Barcelona ‘will not exercise’ option
body: Man Utd forward Marcus Rashford could be heading to another club in Spain after Barcelona decided against buying him, according to reports.

The Red Devils allowed Rashford to leave Old Trafford in the summer transfer window on loan to Barcelona with the Spanish side having a €30m clause to make the deal permanent at the end of the season.
Rashford has contributed six goals and eight assists in 23 matches in all competitions for the Catalan giants with the England international doing okay for Hansi Flick’s side.

Man Utd are committed to selling Rashford, with transfer expert Fabrizio Romano claiming in mid-November that Barcelona will take their time over their decision over whether to take up their buy option.
Romano said: “Marcus Rashford has a €30m buy option for Barcelona. Barca will not decide now in November. Barca will not decide in one month, in December. Barca will take their time.
“They are very happy with Rashford. The numbers are very good. The attitude is very good. So Rashford is doing very well in Barcelona, but Barcelona will take their time.

“At the same time, for Barcelona or anywhere else, Rashford is expected to leave Manchester United on a permanent transfer in 2026. So Rashford is expected to go out, also Hojlund is expected to leave on a permanent transfer.”

But now Spanish website Fichajes insists that the Catalan giants ‘will not exercise its €30 million option to buy Marcus Rashford, an amount they consider beyond their reach in the current economic climate’.

It is understood that his impact on the pitch ‘have been valued internally’ but that Barcelona have ‘decided to end its relationship with Marcus Rashford and focus its efforts on a more sustainable alternative’ with Man City winger Savinho linked.
Another story from the same publication claims that Rashford now has a ‘new destination’ with Atletico Madrid ‘prepared to pay’ the €30m that Man Utd want to complete his departure.

With Rashford ‘keen to stay’ in Spain, a move to Atletico could be the perfect transfer, the report adds: ‘The Atlético de Madrid coaching staff highly value Marcus Rashford’s profile. His ability to attack space, his physique, and his experience in high-level matches fit perfectly with the demands of Simeone’s system.
‘Furthermore, Atlético de Madrid believe that paying 30 million euros for a proven player is a reasonable investment and consistent with the club’s sporting ambitions.’
By choosing Atletico Madrid, it ‘would allow him to compete for important objectives, play in European competitions and assume a relevant role in a stable and competitive project’.
According to reports, one potential Manchester United signing in January is already ‘off’, while three players ‘could quit’ the Premier League giants.
Barcelona have the option to sign the player for €30m and are reportedly becoming more keen to do so.
Marcus Rashford could be in line for a big switch to Atletico Madrid, with the La Liga giants ready to go after him amid “significant doubts” at Barcelona.
Marcus Rashford could reportedly return to Man Utd in the summer transfer window as Barcelona hit a ‘major problem’ over a potential permanent deal.
Former Tottenham scout Bryan King has suggested Spurs are “scraping around for players” amid links to Marcus Rashford, who he wouldn’t sign given a lack of loyalty.
A very silly report has claimed that FC Barcelona have decided to include Marcus Rashford in a swap deal with La Liga rivals Atletico Madrid.

headline: Premier League winners and losers: Villa ‘genius’, ‘irrelevant’ Howe, Raya, Nuno sack, Man Utd and Liverpool
body: The Christmas fixtures delivered one particular theme which tied Arsenal, Liverpool and Manchester United together, with Eddie Howe and Nuno for the sack.
There are also bountiful words for Aston Villa, Everton, David Raya and a great deal more.

When the match-winning substitute can give a lucid and precise description of his manager’s “tactical genius” immediately after such a euphoric and ludicrous victory, it really does underline how ridiculous a job Unai Emery has done at Aston Villa.
“He changed it,” Ollie Watkins said, “because Chelsea were going man for man but they had the extra centre-back when we were going long.

“So when I came on second half he brought Sancho on the wing and Morgan [Rogers] and I think it gave us a little bit more space and then put Youri [Tielemans] in the No. 10 so we had an extra body up there.”

It was the response to a simple enough soft ball of a post-match question – “what did the manager say to you when you were brought on, and what kind of impact did he want you to make?” – but it emphasised how deeply Emery has imprinted his thoughts, words and ideals on this squad.

The most points from losing positions. The most goals scored by substitutes. And a longer winning streak than all but seven clubs have ever put together in Premier League history. All engineered by one of the biggest manager upgrades ever.
Attack wins you games; defence wins you titles; goalkeepers do the rest and probably aren’t noticed until they drop anything resembling a clanger.
Raya will know that from the criticism he faced after what remains the only game this season in which he has failed to save any of the shots he has faced.

Those are the standards set and maintained by the keeper who has faced the fewest shots on target of any who have started more than one-third of their club’s Premier League games this season, but whose save percentage is the fourth-best in the division.

Few have such a reduced margin for error and as unforgiving a role as the final barrier for such a defensively phenomenal side which rarely gives up chances. Raya’s mentality and focus in that sense is as important as his ability for Arsenal.

And that save from Yankuba Minteh, his second and last of the game in that brief window during which his side otherwise lost control, underlined it: Raya needed elite reflexes, level of concentration and even speed of thought in choosing which hand to use to optimise his chances of keeping the ball out.
The only thing processed quicker was the replay which was immediately added to his remarkably highlights package of equally impressive and important saves in the last few seasons.
“The first shot that they had, they scored the goal and then David had to make another save to maintain the result,” said Arteta of a player who thrives in “the key moments” like few others.
There is currently no better Premier League club at developing and platforming raw attacking talent.

The three biggest sales in Brentford’s history were all of forwards they signed either specifically in the Championship or before they played their first game in the Premier League. For the £24.35m spent on Ivan Toney, Bryan Mbeumo and Yoane Wissa, they received 191 goals and £160m.

But even after a third remodelling of their frontline in consecutive seasons, Brentford’s overhauled output continues to excel. The only club with two players in last season’s 10 top Premier League scorers sold both and can still match Manchester City with a pair of representatives in 2025/26’s top 14.

Neither Kevin Schade nor Igor Thiago are perfect. The former is infuriatingly consistent, while the latter often makes the wrong decision in his final action. But their basic ingredients are tantalising, as was showcased as they summarily dismantled Bournemouth.

The patience Brentford have shown with two club-record signings is being rewarded once more in the continuation of a cycle every bit as impressive as their ability to simply promote an assistant to become first-team manager every few years at no apparent cost to results.
Ruben Amorim has often referred to restoring “the feeling of winning” as being something elevated beyond the actual art of victory itself over the past year.

And for a club which has lost 21 of his 61 games, that is pertinent. It is a sensation many at Manchester United might find completely alien; Amorim himself said they were “just trying to survive” against Newcastle and needed “to feel that we can win sometimes without playing so well”.

The Portuguese appears to have at least inherited the Ole Gunnar Solskjaer and Erik ten Hag knack of absurdly elongating a reign by spacing his wins impeccably, like a nurse overseeing a deliberate deterioration in a patient’s health specifically to keep them on life support while explaining to their loved ones that there’s nothing they can do because the ludicrously expensive medication has to be administered in one needlessly exact, sub-optimal and inflexible way.
Manchester United have not been beaten in consecutive games all season – in either the Premier League or all competitions – and have not lost from a winning position since May.

Amorim, who managed separate losing streaks of two, three and four in his first six months, has already watched his Manchester United win more Premier League matches (eight to seven) and score as many goals (32) in 2025/26 than 2024/25 despite being in charge for nine fewer games this campaign.

It doesn’t bear thinking what atrocities would have been inflicted on a defence of Dalot, Yoro, Fredricson, Heaven and Malacia behind a midfield of Cunha, Fletcher, Ugarte and Dorgu last season. But this version of the club, for all its myriad faults, has undoubted “spirit”.

A third straight win. A fourth assist to sit nicely alongside Harry Wilson’s five goals in what is rapidly becoming a standout individual season. A current top-half spot for a club which had spent the entire campaign waiting for the graphic to switch to show those 11th and below.
But most impressively: Raul Jimenez is 2025’s Eric Cantona. Everyone’s saying it.

If the general theme of the festive schedule’s results was of teams either reinforcing or rediscovering how to win in any circumstance, it is one Liverpool followed so faithfully as to almost squander a two-goal lead against perhaps the worst team to ever grace the Premier League.

The teams in 1st, 2nd, 3rd, 4th and 6th all won their games on December 26 and 27 by a single goal; Liverpool should take solace in doing so against a side both Arsenal and Aston Villa have struggled to beat recently.

Arne Slot was right when he marked out as “progress” that his players have learned “when things go against us, we still need to find a way to win the game”. It sounds simple but for over two months adversity almost automatically meant defeat for Liverpool.
As Mikel Arteta said after Arsenal narrowly beat Brighton: “You win, you learn and you go again. The knock-on effect of winning is incredibly powerful.”

It is something Liverpool are beginning to remember. The steps they have made have been tentative. Three straight wins and a seven-game unbeaten run shows growth while leaving ample room for improvement.
Of course, the teams in 10th and 11th also won by the odd goal. It’s Fulham’s thing but Spurs are somewhat less experienced in that regard.
Their only previous single-goal win came at Elland Road in early October. For their last 1-0 triumph in the Premier League, Spurs must go back to February.
Thomas Frank made a point of praising their “resilience” and “mentality” – and it should be said that after having nine shots to 16 and 38% possession you only really can focus on the immeasurables.
But the Premier League’s best away team can take pride at being able to grind things out like it’s a warm May evening in Bilbao.
In 2022/23 it was Kevin de Bruyne (0.86 to 1.43).
In 2023/24 it was De Bruyne again (1.03 to 1.13).
Then in 2024/25 the De Bruyne hat-trick was completed (0.58 to 0.82).

For three seasons the closest player to matching Erling Haaland’s rate of goals and assists per 90 minutes in the Premier League for Manchester City was De Bruyne. And the only time he came within touching distance was when the Belgian played fewer than half of Haaland’s minutes a couple of seasons ago.

This might not be a rate Cherki can maintain – and he has similarly been given a fraction of Haaland’s minutes. But this is the strongest challenge the Norwegian has ever had from a Manchester City teammate (1.27 to 1.34) and Pep Guardiola must be loving it.
The praise should and will, of course, go to Leeds, Daniel Farke and Dominic Calvert-Lewin for one of the more absurd months of form in Premier League history.

But a special mention is warranted for Aaronson, a player whose complicated relationship with the fanbase and ties to an unloved past regime have made his personal renaissance even more stunning than that of his club, manager or teammate.

The American’s run and pass for the equaliser against Sunderland marked his third assist in seven Premier League games, matching the tally from his first 46. His energy carried Leeds but it is quickly becoming allied with pivotal actions to produce a skillset close to irreplicable in a relegation battle:
A literal quarter of the clean sheets Parker has overseen in his career as a Premier League manager have come against either David Moyes, Everton or David Moyes’ Everton.
He also sounded the “fine margins” klaxon post match so everybody wins. Except usually Burnley.
Only two teams in Europe’s top five leagues have drawn more matches: Celta Vigo and Pisa with eight to Sunderland’s seven.
But more pertinently, Sunderland have been level for 64.3% of their Premier League games this season. The closest side to them is Crystal Palace (56.7%).
Sunderland have spent less time leading in the Premier League this campaign than every team bar the bottom three they are 15 points clear of. Regis Le Bris has created a monster of a team.

Therein lies the innate problem with Eddie Howe and Anthony Gordon’s belief that Newcastle could compartmentalise the insipid defeat to Sunderland and “make it right” a few days later in the Carabao Cup.
The Magpies advanced against Fulham in the continued defence of a trophy very possibly keeping the manager in gainful employment, but there is little “right” about Newcastle currently.

Drawing with Chelsea having led was frustrating; a second straight 1-0 defeat away at a bitter rival is lamentable. Their own mild selection problems notwithstanding, Newcastle should be ashamed at failing to breach one of the more vulnerable Manchester United sides Old Trafford has seen.

But then Howe believes the specific stadium at which Newcastle flatter to deceive on any given matchday to be “irrelevant”. He wants to “look at the performances in isolation” and focus on “what the team’s identity is on that day and how it plays”, as if that would be in any way less damning.

“If it’s home or away, for me, I don’t really care,” added a man who really ought to. The only club with a greater disparity between their home and away results is Brentford, who sit above Newcastle in the table despite being hypocritically bullied by them in the summer.
Their pursuit and capture of Yoane Wissa is perhaps the last time the Magpies properly threw their weight around and asserted themselves; it certainly hasn’t been evident on the pitch.
That striker-based epiphany was brief but beautiful, triggering the only two wins, localised entirely within the space of seven November days, of an increasingly hilariously doomed reign.

It felt like West Ham would simply kick on at that stage, having vanquished Newcastle and Burnley to draw level on points with the latter and in the relegation zone on goal difference alone, with momentum heavily in their favour.
The Hammers can boast a better record than only the Clarets and Wolves since then and have thus been marooned further in the mire: that five-point gap to Nottingham Forest resembles a chasm.

And this is as sustained a slump for the manager as it is the team: in a table of Premier League results since February 1, when Forest apparently sacrificed their soul for a 7-0 thrashing of Brighton at the City Ground, a bottom four of ever-presents reads: Spurs, Nottingham Forest, Nuno Espirito Santo (32 points), West Ham and Wolves.

It would be grounds for a sacking if the best conceivable replacement candidate hadn’t a) been sacked by West Ham before, b) contributed to a relegation in his last Premier League post more than five years ago and c) hadn’t literally already been rejected by the club a few months back.

Given the “what a team” head pat by Pep Guardiola and the physical runaround at a decisive set piece. But ultimately it doesn’t feel like making two substitutions in an exhausting game with in-form Manchester City, the first of which was in the 88th minute, should really be the precursor to an entire weekend spent blaming the officials.

Did Arnaud Kalimuendo – 82 Premier League minutes across eight appearances as a £25m summer signing, 17 minutes and three appearances of which were under Dyche – bring an oil-less lamb curry in for lunch after training or something?
From one of the best teams at converting leads into victories last season, Chelsea have become the joint-worst in terms of wastefulness from winning positions.
Those 13 points squandered would have put them second and in the title race. Instead, this is a Champions League qualification race Chelsea’s recent setbacks suggest they don’t have the stomach for.

The watching world knew what was coming when they failed to press home their advantage at home to Aston Villa. It is worrying that Enzo Maresca either didn’t or simply could not adequately react to stem the tide.

Even with the innate outcome bias of judging a manager’s substitutions, Villa scoring within four and one minute of Emery sending players on from the bench can only reflect miserably on the coach who responded with an ineffective triple change and by removing his best forward when chasing a goal.
David Moyes “wouldn’t have wanted to come and watch that myself,” even if he did offer mitigation in the absences of Iliman Ndiaye, Kiernan Dewsbury-Hall and Jack Grealish.
Remove the three foremost attacking fulcrums from any team and their subsequent creative struggles would be expected.

But this should not be mistaken as a slump related only to AFCON, injury and curiously timed Christmas illnesses. Everton have laboured in this department all season: Wolves and West Ham are the only sides with fewer goals and different individual scorers respectively.

The 14 players Moyes used at Turf Moor had a combined 78 Premier League career goals, to which their 55-year-old centre-half pairing contributed more than a third. Dwight McNeil, who last scored in the competition in May, accounted for more than a quarter by himself.
Everton’s highest shot taker in the Premier League this season, James Garner, has three goals in 103 games for the Toffees.
It is almost like exclusively speculating to accumulate in attack by spending upwards of £100m on talented but undeveloped and unrefined players might not be the best idea.
This is what you get for going beyond your station.

The descent beyond mere Derby 2007/08 territory continues. Wolves are five defeats away from breaking the record for longest losing streak in a single Premier League season, having already set a new bar for longest winless start and myriad other miserable markers.

There have been just enough narrow defeats – 1-0 to both Aston Villa and Nottingham Forest; 2-1 to both Arsenal and Liverpool – in recent weeks to sustain the illusion of progress, but Wolves have not done so much as lead a game in almost three entire months.

Rob Edwards was brought in with more than one eye on a future in the Championship, yet it has to be considered whether this is doing irreparable damage to his reputation with the fanbase, players and board.

While he ranks absurdly far down the list of individuals to be held accountable for this historic failure, this has already eroded Edwards’ goodwill, leeway, patience and momentum ahead of a summer in which more players will be sold and promotion will be the expectation.

Seven straight defeats with barely a whimper was basically baked into his appointment, yet the longer this goes on – and every indication is that it will – the weaker the foundations Edwards ultimately actually comes to build on will be.
Time to consult the ‘Has Fabian Hurzeler Literally Ever Won A Game Of Association Football As A Manager In December’ updater:
No.

Eleven games, six draws, five defeats for the German as Brighton head coach in literally the busiest month of the Premier League calendar. As impressive as that level of solidarity with the Bundesliga winter break is, it isn’t ideal.

headline: Premier League prize money table predicted as Liverpool jump back above Manchester United
body: Three teams have been picked for more Premier League TV games than Arsenal, Liverpool and Chelsea this season. Manchester United, obviously, but also…

Premier League clubs received a total of £2.83billion last season, which was comprised of six payments through the division’s ‘central revenue system’, something the Premier League says ‘ensures the most equitable distribution of funds of any major European league’.
Liverpool were paid £174.9m as champions – short of Manchester City’s record £176.2m in 2022/23 – while Newcastle received just over £160m to chuck into their PSR black hole.
Southampton were handed £109.2m for their efforts in finishing a distant bottom. It pays to be in the Premier League.

Some of those payments are fixed. All 20 clubs automatically receive around £96.9m through an equal share distributed based on both the domestic (£29.8m in 2024/25) and international (£59.2m in 2024/25) broadcast deals – those TV rights are lucrative for a reason – as well as £7.9m each from central commercial revenue streams.
The rest is variable, based on where clubs finish and how often their games are selected for broadcast.
The Premier League merit payments are distributed on a sliding scale from 1st to 20th, made up of combined earnings from domestic and international broadcast deals.

For the 2024/25 season, the difference in prize money was around £2.7m per position. Southampton were given as much for finishing bottom, all the way up to champions Liverpool receiving £53.1m. It basically helped pay for 97.4% of Giorgi Mamardashvili and Jeremie Frimpong.
That can be expected to fluctuate with inflation and other factors – it was around £2.8m per position in 2023/24 – but it offers a rough guide as to what clubs should expect to earn this season.

The only other part of the prize money which is not fixed and shared equally are the facility fees, which are based on how many times each club has been selected for television.

In 2024/25, Liverpool had 30 games televised in the UK, for which they received £24.9m in facility fees. Arsenal had 29 matches and were paid £24.2m, while Manchester United (28 games for £23.4m), Aston Villa (27 games for £22.6m) and Chelsea (26 games for £21.8m) were televised frequently and rewarded handsomely.
Ipswich were shown on the fewest occasions and received £8.9m in facility fees for their 10 live televised UK fixtures.

This can lead to discrepancies in terms of those variable payments. Manchester United’s prize money after finishing 15th last season was £136.2m, more than the four clubs immediately above them – West Ham (£130.9m in 14th), Everton (£131.8m in 13th), Crystal Palace (£136.1m in 12th) and Fulham (£135.5m in 11th) – as Ruben Amorim’s side were picked for far more live TV games.
Spurs were another massive outlier, earning more in 17th (£127.8m) than Wolves did in 16th (£123.1m) in part because they had nine more games picked for live UK broadcast.
